letters.incipit: I advertised his Majesty long
letters.abstract: This document is a letter dated December 21, 1607, from Sir Henry Wotton to the Earl of Salisbury, detailing the transmission of a portrait of Father Paolo Sarpi to King James I after a previous attempt to send it failed, noting Sarpi's recent recovery from an attack and enhancing his portrait with the depiction of his scars. Wotton discusses the role and reputation of Captain Nicolas Pinner, who is being sent home on confidential matters and who hopes to gain military command in Ulster. The letter also includes remarks on Sarpi's cautious nature and the declining influence of the Papacy.
letters.transcription:
114. To THE EARL OF SALISBURY
S. P. Ven., holograph, extract. Wotton sends another portrait of Sarpi.
The 21st of December, 1607.
. . . Your Lordship’s of the 12th of November came yesterday
into my hands very opportunely, being then ready to dispatch Captain
Pinner² towards his Majesty upon weighty and secret occasions,
whom I have now retained a day or two, that he may bring with
him the picture of P(adre) P(aolo),³ which his Majesty shall now,
through the miscarriage of the former, receive with the late
addition of his scars. And I have this morning communicated
with him those papers as from his Majesty, whose gracious
remembrances¹ he taketh very dearly and tenderly.

¹ Bedell wrote to Ward in an undated letter, but written about this time,
of Sarpi, “Now thanked be God he is perfectly recovered and abroad again, and
I do hope this accident will awake him a little more, and put some more spirit
in him, which is his only want; although to say truth it is rather judgement
and discretion in him—considering this State how it stands—than weakness
that makes him cautelous. I have no doubt but by little and little the Papacy
will to wrack.” (Two Biographies, p. 225.)
² Captain Nicolas Pinner (ante, p. 365), who was now returning home in the
hopes of obtaining a command in Ulster, where he had formerly served. “One
of your Majesty’s honest and valiant subjects,” Wotton wrote of him to the
King, “that thought to have spent his blood in the late variance here.” (S. P.
Ven., Jan. 11, 1607.) He also recommended him to Salisbury, “in this narrow
time for his profession, when princes are so wise that soldiers must be poor.”
(Ibid.)
³ For this portrait see Appendix III, Sarpi.

letters.incipit: The last week we had the letters of Flanders very late
letters.abstract: This letter provides a snapshot of Venetian politics in early 1607, showcasing Wotton’s continued engagement in espionage and diplomatic maneuvering. The harsh sentencing of Angelo Badoero highlights Venice’s strict control over internal affairs, while Wotton’s depiction of Archduke Ferdinand as a Jesuit puppet aligns with broader English fears of Catholic influence. The dramatic account of Sir Julius Caesar’s son’s death adds an element of personal tragedy, linking the diplomatic narrative to English interests. Wotton’s conspiratorial mindset remains evident in his framing of events. He portrays the Jesuits as omnipresent manipulators, the Papal Nuncio as a scheming but ineffective agent, and Venice as heroically resisting foreign encroachment. His letter serves both as intelligence and as a piece of rhetorical persuasion, reinforcing England’s perception of Catholic powers as inherently conspiratorial.
letters.transcription:
Letter 118: To The Earl of Salisbury
Source: S. P. Ven., holograph, extract.
Topics: Foreign news delayed by wintry weather; sentence on Angelo Badoero; death of a son of Sir Julius Caesar.
Date: Venice, January 18, 1607(8).
Transcription
Right Honourable and My Very Good Lord,
The last week we had the letters of Flanders very late, and this week none at all, the courier of Antwerp being (for aught we yet know) drowned on the way in the snows, which through Italy are increased, and in the nearer countries, beyond memory and almost example. Yet we have cleared ourselves of the vain conceit touching the surprise of Bolduc.
The Diet of Germany is as cold as the weather, some princes refusing to send thither so much as their ambassadors, and few appearing personally, through a general distaste taken against the Emperor for making the Archduke Ferdinando his representative, a prince wholly in the power of the Jesuits.
Here the case of the Cavalier Angelo Badoero hath been now published in the Grand Council in this form, that having passed determinedly between him and the public minister of a prince here resident, with consent of two friars, in the cell of one of them, a secret conference from two hours before sunset till more than two hours of the night, without any notice thereof given by him to the State, either before or after; he hath therefore been sentenced by the Council of Ten to remain one whole year in prison; which term expired, to be afterwards for ever incapable at home of entering into any of the secret councils, and abroad of receiving any annual benefit from any foreign prince, in which case he shall be understood guilty of rebellion; moreover, that if ever he shall depart out of the Venetian dominion he shall be understood ex tunc definitely banished, and his goods confiscated. The two friars in twenty-four hours to depart the city, and in three days the dominion, upon pain of death; which hath been accordingly executed, notwithstanding the Nuncio his intercession against that point only of the sentence, with notorious simplicity and derision, being an interested party in the case, and (to make up the sport) he is said in College to have let fall these words, that the Pope should know of it, as it were by way of commination, at which they could scant even before him hold their countenances.
Thus have I now once more troubled your Lordship with this gentleman’s process, wherein I must add this farther, that he failed in the first ballotation, but two balls of losing his head on a public scaffold and the friars of being drowned.
For the conclusion of the present, I must advertise your Lordship of the disastrous end at Padua of Sir Julius Caesar’s eldest son, who two days since in the morning was slain in the public street by the usher of a fencer, from whom he had the day before in his own school received some affront.
I have advertised his father of the particularity thereof by Captain Pinner, whom my letter will overtake in Augusta, being departed hence but two days since with a very important dispatch unto his Majesty, and the picture mentioned in your Lordship’s last.
And so for the present I commit your Lordship to the God of Heaven.
Your Lordship’s always bound to honour and serve you,
HENRY WOTTON

Application of the GraCM Matrix (Grammar of Conspiracy in Historical Texts)

letters.incipit: Having at the present sufficiently troubled your Lordship
letters.abstract: Writing from Venice on 28 March 1608, Henry Wotton informs the Earl of Salisbury that King James I’s Apologia pro Iuramento Fidelitatis (a defense of the Oath of Allegiance) has arrived and circulated among Venetian leadership. Even before Wotton could present a copy to the Doge formally, the Doge had already received one from England and consulted with a “party” (almost certainly Paolo Sarpi). The book has sparked discussion among “residents and other instruments of state.” Wotton requests more copies of the Apologia and additional Protestant works (referencing a catalog Salisbury sent), hoping to distribute them in Venice for “a great many” who might be receptive. In particular, he wants small–format editions of Bishop John Jewel’s Apology, well–suited for discreet circulation and influencing Venetian opinion. Wotton closes by noting a brewing conflict in Austria between Emperor Rudolf II and his brother Archduke Matthias, stemming from a dispute over religious freedom in Hungary and adjacent regions.
letters.transcription:
TO THE EARL OF SALISBURY
Venice, the 28th of March, 1608 (Style of the place)
	RIGHT HONOURABLE AND MY VERY GOOD LORD,
	Having at the present sufficiently troubled your Lordship with the enclosed papers, I will defer the discourses and opinions of this place touching the Act of Renunciation (which you require in the postscript of your last) till the next post, by which time I shall also have perceived what effect those books (which came with your said dispatch) are likely to work here. In the meanwhile, it may please his Majesty to know that before I could convey one of them handsomely to the hands of the Duke of Venice (for publicly in some respects which shall be signified I forbore to do it), he had gotten one from England, and communicated the same with the party your Lordship knoweth, whom he sent for of purpose to his private lodgings. Since then the matter is dispersed among the residents and other instruments of state upon the place, and it is grown (as is fit it should) a subject of much discourse.
	I beseech your Lordship (according to your promise) that I may have more of them, and likewise of those other authors (whereof you have sent me a catalogue) touching the progress of reformation and steps (as I may call it) of the Truth, which, because they will make a bigger bulk, may be sent by sea; and I assure your Lordship here is a State where we shall find vent for a great many of them, in which respect I must be bold to wish that Jewell’s Apology were reprinted in the little form, and some two hundred of them sent me; for being besides the matter eloquently penned, and in respect of the smallness of easy dispersion, I can think of nothing so proper for these young Christians.
	My next unto your Lordship is likely to be very troublesome, in foresight whereof I will here end the present; committing your safety to the God of Heaven, and for all your favours humbly resting,
	Your Lordship’s always bound to honour and serve you,
HENRY WOTTON.
	Our news out of Austria inclineth to some notable division between the Emperor and his brother Mathias, who having (as it should seem by sufficient warrant) confirmed unto the Hungarians and adjacent provinces the liberty of conscience, which the Emperor would retract, the matter beginneth to grow unto public arms, Moravia being already in motu. God bless His own cause.
(Some minor spelling regularized and bracketed text removed for clarity.)
Conspiratorial Analysis
	1.	Covert or Discreet Distribution of Books
	•	Wotton carefully avoids presenting the Apologia to the Doge “publicly” for “some respects which shall be signified.” This implies a cautious, quasi–secret method of introducing Protestant works into a Catholic state—soft propaganda aimed at winning favor with Venice’s ruling circles.
	2.	Reliance on “the Party Your Lordship Knoweth”
	•	Wotton alludes to a known confidant (almost certainly Fra Paolo Sarpi) whom the Doge “sent for” to discuss James’s book. This indicates an insider or collaborator within Venice’s administration to facilitate or interpret the text, again hinting at behind–the–scenes religious and political maneuvering.
	3.	Appeal for More Material (“Vent for a Great Many”)
	•	Wotton’s encouragement that large shipments of reformation texts be sent “by sea” underscores the scale of his ambition—quietly saturating Venetian intellectual circles with Protestant arguments to diminish papal authority in the region.
	4.	Wider European Implications
	•	The letter also mentions a significant Habsburg family conflict over religious liberties in Austria and Hungary. Connecting these Austrian troubles with the Venetian scenario, Wotton frames both as part of a larger tension between Protestant or libertarian forces and reactionary Catholic rulers. Thus, he sees these theological controversies as potentially conspiratorial in nature, with shifting alliances threatening old power structures.
Overall, while Wotton’s tone remains diplomatic, his request for discreet distribution of books and acknowledgment of an in–State ally reveals a low–key propaganda campaign that can be seen as conspiratorial from a Roman Catholic viewpoint.

letters.incipit: SUCH PARTICULARS AS I HEAR FROM ROME TOUCHING TIRONE.
letters.abstract: This letter, dated from Venice in May (?), 1608, relays intelligence from Rome concerning Tyrone’s activities. According to the report, Tyrone—accompanied largely by the Primate of Ireland—visited various cardinals and ambassadors. From Cardinals Farnese and Mont’ Alto he received favorable words. In Rome, among a group dispatched from the English College (including Thomas Fitzharbert and John Sweete), he was noted for his interaction with English exiles. Notably, upon seeing Sir Anthony Standen, he is reputed to have declared that “it is better being poor in Rome than rich in prison in England.” Furthermore, the letter details two private audiences with the Pope, mentions his lodging in a palace alongside the Persian ambassador and Sir Anthony Sherly, and reports that the Pope intends to limit his board to twelve persons amid rising discontent. Rumors include a pension of ten thousand crowns per annum from the King of Spain for the support of the Irish, along with scattered personal observations regarding Tyrone’s wife. Overall, the letter interweaves documented diplomatic encounters with rumor, reflecting the intricate network of political, religious, and personal intrigues among exiled English and Irish figures in Rome.
letters.transcription:
131.	To THE EAKL OF SALISBURY.
S. P. Yen., holograph, undated. Printed in CaL S. P. Ireland, 1606–8, p. 655.
Tyrone left Milan about the middle of April. On May 9 Wotton wrote, “All Italy doth ring of his reception in Rome.” (S. P. Ven.; Cal. S. P. Ireland, p. 657.) The following “particulars” were sent probably later on in May.
(Venice, May (?), 1608.)
SUCH PARTICULARS AS I HEAR FROM ROME TOUCHING TIRONE.
He hath visited (for the most part in the company of the Primate of Ireland²) the cardinals and ambassadors. From the Cardinals Farnese and Mont’ Alto³ he received kindest words and countenance, according to his own opinion of them.
Among other coaches that encountered him before his entry there was one (which Parsons had borrowed) sent as from the English College, wherein were Thomas Fitzharbert*, John Sweete², and a third (whose name is not signified) in quality of speakers for the rest.
Among the English that met him in the city he spoke reverently of his Majesty, and railed on your Lordship most extremely. Upon the sight of Sir Anthony Standen³ he is said to have used these words — “Sir Anthony, it is better being poor in Rome than rich in prison in England.” He hath had two private audiences with the Pope, who seemeth to have promised him a consistorial hearing. He is lodged in the Palace⁴ where the Persian ambassador and Sir Anthony Sherly were placed, and the Pope intendeth to reduce his board to twelve persons: at which they say he hath taken much discontentment.
In his coach (as is written unto me) he commonly sitteth in portella a basso (peradventure to be seen) and the Primate in capo, and Tirconel⁵ on his left hand.
The speech runneth in Rome that the King of Spain hath assigned a pension in grosse of ten thousand crowns per annum for the sustentation of the Irish there: whereof I shall penetrate the truth by farther means.
His wife is much commended and admired for her beauty and modesty of behaviour: yet one writeth unto me somewhat wantonly of the matter, that he hath done well to bring her to Rome in case all other means should shrink.
I protest unto your Lordship I cannot abstain from mingling sport with this subject; which seemeth every day unto me more and more contemptible and inconsiderable, as I shall take the boldness to discourse unto his Majesty in my next.
*Footnotes:
*1 Thomas Fitzharbert (1552–1640), a Jesuit, accused of conspiring to poison Queen Elizabeth. He went to Rome in 1602, acting for twelve years as agent for the English clergy. (D. N. U.)
*2 John Sweete, alias Douse (1572–1632), for some time penitentiary at St. Peter’s in Rome. (Foley, vi, p. 228.)
*3 Sir Anthony Standen, a person of strange character, formerly employed by Walsingham as a spy, later attached to the Earl of Essex. Knighted by Elizabeth, he was sent on James’s accession with letters from the King to Venice and the Duke of Florence. Imprisoned in the Tower on his return to England. (Lodge’s Illustrations, 1791, iii, p. 164 n.)
*4 Palazzo della Rovere, where Sir Anthony Sherly and the so‐called Persian ambassador (and Wotton with them) were lodged in 1601 (see ante, p. 38).
*5 Rory O’Donnell, Earl of Tyrconnel, died July 28, 1608. (S. P. Yen., Aug. 15.) “For further mention of Tyrone in Wotton’s dispatches, see Cal. S. P. Irish, 1606–8, pp. 656, 661, 662, 664, 666–70.”

letters.incipit: Having both extraordinary occasion and a fit opportunity
letters.abstract: In this letter, Wotton informs the Earl of Salisbury about a significant defection in Venice: Monsignor Ribetta, the vicar of the Patriarch, has fled to Rome under the influence of the Patriarch himself, who is allegedly seeking a cardinalship. The Senate reacts to this betrayal by curbing the Patriarch’s financial privileges rather than taking harsher measures. Wotton draws a parallel to Henry VIII’s dissolution of monasteries, suggesting that this restriction will prevent the return of the Jesuits. He also expresses gratitude for Salisbury’s support of his countryman, John Finett, and concludes with a reference to his own unprofitability in service.
letters.transcription:
Letter 145: To the Earl of Salisbury
S. P. Ven., holograph, no date, endorsed ‘rec. pr. Jan’. Flight of the Patriarch’s vicar to Rome; John Finett, &c.
(Venice, December 1608)
Transcription
RIGHT HONOURABLE AND MY VERY GOOD LORD,
Having both extraordinary occasion and a fit opportunity of writing to your Lordship within three or four days, by an Italian gentleman (whom I shall be bold, among my other presumptions, to recommend unto your honourable favour), I should by this post say nothing, were it not for an accident happened here this last week of much noise.
Monsignor Ribetta, the vicar here of the Patriarch, and one of the seven Theologi (who jointly published certain propositions against the validity of the Pope’s excommunication), under pretense of some business abroad, is secretly fled to Rome; induced thereunto partly by the example of Fulgentio the Franciscan, whom the Pope useth not ill (as they have indeed the art of fostering examples), and likewise by the persuasion of the Patriarch himself (as hath been since known), who, in hope of a cardinalship, undertook the working of this man. He hath hereby increased the ill conceit of the Senate towards him, where it is taken very sensitively; but himself being at the present hectical, and not likely long to escape, they have manifested their anger no farther than in the limitation of that faculty, which the Pope gave him, to dispense the intrate which the Jesuits drew out of this State, amounting (as I am now informed by the particulars) to the point of 20,000 crowns per annum.
For having been well considered that the Pope might buy a great deal of goodwill with such a sum laid out to his advantage yearly, the Senate seemeth resolved only to take a note from the Patriarch of such persons as shall seem fit unto him, and to make the distribution afterwards as shall seem fit to themselves.
Now there is likely to ensue upon this a secondary good, that the clergy, priests, and friars (who shall participate of this intrata) will leave no saint unprayed unto to keep out the Jesuits, somewhat (in a smaller proportion) like unto that course of Henry VIII in the division of the abbey lands, for which the only wise God be ever thanked.
This is all wherewith I will trouble your Lordship at the present, being in a little time to make a very important dispatch unto his Majesty, by the joint deliberation of the best affected here.
It shall be fit for me to conclude with many humble thanks, as for the rest of your favours, so for the late honours which it pleased your Lordship to do unto mine honest countryman and friend, Mr. John Finett, and in him to me, and for the confidence which your Lordship hath, and may justly repose in him, for the serving of my Lord your son in his travels; whom, according to your Lordship’s speech unto me in your bed at my departure (whereof I have forgot nothing), I may now hope to see in this poor house, before his Majesty call me from this charge, where I have been so unprofitable unto him, and resolve me again into those plain and simple elements whereof I am compounded.
In the meantime and always I humbly rest,
Your Lordship’s most bound to honour and serve you,

letters.incipit: From Rome we hear that Poma
letters.abstract: In this dispatch of fifth December 1608 from Venice, Sir Henry Wotton informs the Earl of Salisbury that Ridolfo Poma, implicated in the failed attempt on Fra Paolo Sarpi’s life, now enjoys guarded favor in Rome, causing the Pope an awkward dilemma between leniency and exposing the Church’s role in sponsoring assassins. Wotton further reveals two new conspiracies uncovered against Sarpi, including one hatched by his own “converse” and relatives from Viterbo. Meanwhile, Lord Roos has arrived in Venice and fallen ill, yet demonstrates a resolute aversion to Catholicism. Finally, Wotton outlines a covert plan to free the imprisoned Mr. Mole by funneling funds through Nicholas Fitzherbert, who hopes to regain King James’s favor.
letters.transcription:
TO THE EARL OF SALISBURY
From Venice, the 5th of December, 1608
	… From Rome we hear that Poma (the suborner of him who gave the blow to the Friar Paulo) flying thither, was received by the Cardinal Ascanio Colonna then living, who was the head of the practice which he had consulted with the Cardinal Borghesi. This Poma of late, upon some private accusation (whereof the secret is yet unknown) having been apprehended by the Pope’s sergeants—in the resistance of them (for which even the minions of cardinals have lost their lives)—was hurt, and is now (though in prison) much cherished by the Pope, who seemeth to stand in a great dilemma. If he let him go, how palpable will be his protection of assassinates; if he punish him, who will give any more blows for the Church?
	There is detected two other conspiracies against the person of the said friar, the one revealed unto him by his own converse, a Roman, who had been practised withal to make him away, by two sent hither of purpose (his kinsmen) from Viterbo. The other instrument should have been one of his own order in Padua, who (as I hear) likewise revealed it himself. These are the effects and proper character of that purpurissata meretrix …
	Here is newly arrived the Lord Rosse, and St. Jhons, who hath been ill welcomed with a violent fever, whereof yet we hope the worst is past.
	With the Lord Rosse I have dealt very seriously touching the Roman journey, and find in his speeches a most vehement detestation of that foolish religion. Touching Mr. Mole, I have propounded a course unto my Lord Rosse for his delivery, which shall be to transport by oblique means to the hands of Nicholas Fitzherbert some portion of money, as well for the present necessities of the said Mole, as also to be disposed to the helping of him out, by the discretion of Fitzherbert, to whom I mean to write that by this deed he shall win good opinion from his Majesty, by whose grace he hath long desired to return home. This is the probablest way that we can take for the helping of that poor gentleman, without spending any suit in it.
	H. WOTTON.
(Minor spelling regularized and bracketed phrases removed for clarity.)

letters.incipit: The resident ambassador of the Signory at Rome
letters.abstract: This letter reports the reaction of Pope Paul V to the preaching of Fra Fulgenzio Micanzio, which had stirred controversy in Venice. The Venetian ambassador in Rome informed the Duke of Venice that the Pope, after hearing complaints from Cardinal Lanfranco, angrily denounced Fulgenzio’s sermons, asserting that preaching the pure Gospel and Scripture amounted to an attack on the Catholic faith. The Venetian Senate, upon hearing this remark, reacted with murmurs and scandal, perceiving the Pope’s words as proof of the Church’s suppression of biblical teaching. Paolo Sarpi (Padre Paulo), a leading Venetian theologian, saw this as a key moment in exposing Rome’s hostility toward religious reform, believing it would help open the eyes of the Venetian authorities to papal overreach. This letter underscores the widening rift between Venice and Rome, highlighting the Venetian desire for religious independence and the increasing tension over Protestant-leaning reforms within the Republic.
letters.transcription:
To THE EARL OF SALISBURY
S. P. Ven., holograph, extract
Venice, the 24th of April, 1609 (Style of the place)
	… The resident ambassador of the Signory at Rome hath written to this Duke that the Pope himself, having (after the Cardinal Lanfranco) expostulated with him touching the sermons of Fulgentio, he gave him this answer, that the said Fulgentio (as he had been informed from hence) did preach but the Gospel and word of God. Et non sapete voi (replied the Pope in a great passion) che il predicare la pura Scrittura et il puro Evangelio è un voler ruinare et distruggere la fede catholica? These were his formal words; which being rehearsed in Senate out of the ambassador’s letter, did cause a general murmur and scandal amongst them.
And Padre Paulo is of opinion that nothing was to be wished more for the opening of their eyes here than such a voice from the Pope himself.

letters.incipit: They have here within these two days
letters.abstract: In this letter from Venice, Henry Wotton informs the Earl of Salisbury about recent events concerning the punishment of friars. A friar who had been exiled for aiding secret communications between the Papal Nuncio and Angelo Badoero was caught returning and sentenced to ten years of imprisonment. Another monk from Perugia, allegedly involved in a plot to assassinate Maestro Paulo (Paolo Sarpi), was executed in secrecy by the Venetian Council of Ten. Wotton notes that while these occurrences may seem minor compared to the affairs of other English agents abroad, he believes they signal larger developments in Venice. He then requests a brief hiatus in his correspondence, citing medical advice to visit the Baths of Abano for treatment of a suspected kidney or bladder ailment.
letters.transcription:
153. To the Earl of Salisbury
S. P. Ven., holograph, extract. Monks punished; Wotton going to the baths of Abano.
From Venice, this 1st of May, 1609.
… They have here within these two days sentenced to ten years’ close imprisonment the friar who, a year since, was banished for lending the Nuntio and Angelo Badoero his cell during their secret conference, and now presumed to return, not only within their territory, but to his former convent in this city, where he was apprehended.
And it is said that another monk of Perugia (who under some colours came hither to practise the death of Maestro Paulo) was this week by sentence of the Council of Ten drowned secretly in the night.
Thus do I entertain your Lordship with nothing but the chastisement of friars, while from other of his Majesty’s servants abroad you receive subjects of greater noise; but I hope God doth, under these small accidents, intend some excellent and admirable work in this place.
I must now humbly crave your Lordship’s pardon for this next fortnight’s silence, unless some important occasion of writing fall out; for I am advised by my physicians after my late sickness to take a little fresh air, and to drink of a mineral water near Padua at the Baths of Abano, against a calculous disposition whereof I am somewhat afraid.
God keep your Lordship in His safe and dear protection.
Your Lordship’s always bound to honour and serve you,
Henry Wotton.

letters.incipit: Postscript. — Before the departure of this bearer
letters.abstract: Henry Wotton relays Maestro Paolo (Paolo Sarpi)’s suggestion that England mediate between the Dutch Republic and Venice by encouraging the former to report on their treaty negotiations, subtly fostering closer ties without Venice appearing to seek them directly. Sarpi argues that England, as the “balancer of Christendom,” is best positioned for such a role, allowing Venice to maintain a posture of passive prudence while still benefiting from the alliance. Wotton questions why Venice does not initiate this exchange through its own ambassador in England, but Sarpi insists that Venetian diplomacy prefers indirect engagement. The proposal extends to Brandenburg’s claim to Cleves, recognizing shifting German alliances as another diplomatic opportunity. Wotton closes by noting that Giovanni Francesco Biondi, if still in England, could prepare the ground for these negotiations as part of his upcoming travels. The letter reflects the covert nature of early modern diplomacy, where states maneuvered carefully to advance their interests while maintaining strategic discretion.
letters.transcription:
Postscript. — Before the departure of this bearer M. P. [Maestro Paolo] did secretly confer with me a conceit of his own not impertinent to the premises, which was this in substance: that if the States of the United Provinces, might by his Majesty’s means, be incited to give by an ambassador some account of the issue of their treaty to this Signiory, it would be corresponded with the like, and so a farther friendship might kindle between them, upon a fair occasion, for the common good. And he added that if the Marquis of Brandenburg shall be settled in the Dukedom of Cleves (as is likeliest by our intelligence) the like occasion may be taken by him also, which I shall have opportunity to further in the German journey.
	I replied (out of a former letter from your Lordship) with some marvel why this Signory did not by their own resident in England motion the matter to the resident there of the States, rather than addorse it upon his Majesty. And he answered, that his Majesty was here contemplated for the balancer of Christendom, who therefore had a proper interest in all such good propositions. “Besides, this State (quoth he) will not seem to seek it, but I know they will take it if it be offered, being governed at the present con una certa specie di prudentia più tosto passiva che attiva.”
	If your Lordship have not before the arrival of this bearer dispatched Biondi (much bound unto you, as he professeth in all his letters), then it may please his Majesty, according to his royal resolution about my journey, to let him prepare the way against my coming in any of those Courts through which he passeth, being a very faithful and zealous negotiator.
(Note: Slight modernization of punctuation and bracketed clarifications for reading ease.)

letters.incipit: About the time of this bearer's departure,
letters.abstract: In this letter, Wotton expresses deep concern over the systematic targeting of English Protestant travelers in Catholic Europe, particularly their tutors, whom he claims are being deliberately separated from their students by Jesuit-influenced authorities. He recounts the arrest of Edward Lichefeld by Dominican friars and his imprisonment by the Inquisition, paralleling it with similar cases, including that of Mr. Mole in Rome. Wotton portrays the Jesuits as covert manipulators within the Papal court, orchestrating intelligence operations to preemptively monitor and influence English noblemen before they arrive in Rome. His language reflects both real geopolitical tensions and conspiratorial anxieties, particularly regarding the supposed “reconciliation” of Lichefeld within the Jesuit novitiate, which he suspects to be a strategic fabrication. He highlights the broader trend of religious surveillance and coercion, linking these events to a calculated strategy aimed at undermining Protestant influence in the region. Throughout, Wotton grapples with uncertainty, admitting his growing difficulty in distinguishing reality from deception, reinforcing his broader narrative of Catholic intrigue.
letters.transcription:
Letter 156 Analysis
To the Earl of Salisbury
S. P. Ven., holograph. Postscript to dispatch of June 18. Another English tutor imprisoned by the Inquisition.
Venice, June 18, 1609 (N.S.)
Transcription of the Letter
Right Honourable and My Very Good Lord,
About the time of this bearer’s departure, there has occurred an accident in these parts to one of his Majesty’s subjects, which, seeming unto me a matter of public consequence, I have thought it my duty to represent the same unto his Majesty’s higher wisdom as an appendix to this dispatch.
My Lord Wentworth, on the 18th of May, coming towards Venice (as then immediately from Florence), accompanied with his brother-in-law Mr. Henry Crafts, one Edward Lichefeld, their governor, and some two or three other English, through Bologna, as they were there together at supper the very night of their arrival, came up two Dominican Friars, with the sergeants of the town, and carried thence the foresaid Lichefeld, with all his papers, into the prison of the Inquisition, where he yet remaineth.
Thus standeth this accident in the bare circumstances thereof, not different, save only in place, from that of Mr. Mole at Rome. And doubtlessly (as we collect now upon the whole matter) if Sir John Harington had either gone the Roman journey or taken the ordinary way in his remove hitherwards out of Tuscany, the like would have befallen his director also, a gentleman of singular sufficiency; for it appeareth a new piece of counsel (infused into the Pope by his artisans, the Jesuits) to separate by some device their guides from our young noblemen (about whom they are busiest), and afterwards to use themselves (for aught I can yet hear) with much kindness and security, but yet with restraint (when they come to Rome) of departing thence without leave; which form was held both with the Lords Rosse and St. Johns, and with this Lord Wentworth and his brother-in-law at their being there.
And we have at the present also a like example or two in Barons of the Almain nation of our religion, whose governors are imprisoned at Rome and Ferrara; so as the matter seemeth to pass into a rule. And albeit hitherto those (before-named) of our own be escaped out of that Babylon (as far as I can penetrate) without any bad impressions, yet surely it appeareth very dangerous to leave our travellers in this contingency; especially being dispersed in the middle towns of Italy (whither the language doth most draw them) certain nimble pleasant wits in quality of interceptors, who deliver over to their correspondents at Rome the dispositions of gentlemen before they arrive, and so subject them both to attraction by argument and attraction by humour.
I must not conceal from his Majesty that (according to my intelligence from Rome) the above-named Lichefeld was there reconciled (as they term it) in the novitiate of the Jesuits; which, being incompatible with his present imprisonment, and much more with his own confusion at the time of his taking, I dare not believe, growing every day to me (as I must confess) more and more uncertain whom I shall think white or black, through the skill of the Jesuits, who knowing that example and number have vim aggregandi, work upon report and, either dead or alive, blemish all alike.

letters.incipit: This worthy Duke,
letters.abstract: In this letter, Henry Wotton describes his formal presentation of King James I’s book to the Doge of Venice, framing the occasion as an auspicious event occurring on St. James’s Day. Wotton elaborates on the significance of monarchs engaging in writing, reinforcing James’s literary work as a testament to his wisdom and leadership. He draws a direct connection between the book and England’s stance on sovereignty, particularly in response to the Papal influence, likening the Pope’s interference in secular affairs to the uncontrollable flooding of the Tiber. Wotton highlights his own role in ensuring that the Doge correctly understands James’s intent—not to interfere with Venetian governance but to assert the necessity of resistance against Papal overreach. The letter reflects Wotton’s diplomatic tact, emphasizing the importance of Venice’s recognition of James’s support while securing Venetian goodwill in the broader Protestant-Catholic struggle.
letters.transcription:
Right Honourable and My Very Good Lord,
This worthy Duke, being recovered of that little indisposition (advertised in my former), I presented unto him on Saturday last (which was St. James’s day) his Majesty’s book and letters, telling him (by way of preparation) that the congiuntura di quel giorno (wherein I then performed this office) was fallen out (though casually) non senza buon augurio, being the day of his Majesty’s happy coronation, wherein the Almighty God had set over us so learned, so wise, and so just a King. And from hence, falling into some discourse of the book, I told him farther, that when princes (who have so many public cares and diversions of their mind) do dispense any portion of their time in writing, every one ought to believe the subject to be most important and proportionable to the height of their degree; as this indeed was which his Majesty had handled, whereof the scope would best appear in the occasion.
And hereupon I fell to deduce unto him the first motive thereof from the powder treason, which occasioned our supreme Court of Parliament (then assembled) to institute an oath of fidelity or allegiance, for the future safety of his Majesty’s royal person (with whom God had so much blessed us) against the practices of the Pope, who by his Jesuits (whom I termed his instrumenti politici) sought (as was now most palpable) in all kingdoms and Signories to nourish a private party against the public obedience.
In which consideration, his Majesty (being tied to some princes by affinity, to others, by particular affection, but to all communi vinculo Maiestatis) did hold it his duty to justify the general cause, and to incite them fraternally to a weighty and serious care thereof in their several dominions. For as the Pope (with which comparison I took the boldness to entertain them) did hold many consulte, and had appointed a special congregation of cardinals to deliberate about the means how to stop the inundations of the Tiber, and to contain the same within his own channel or bounds, so was it now grown as necessary for other princes to consult together how to stop the inundations of Popes themselves, and to contain them within their spiritual pretences; for the question now in hand went no farther.
True it was, that his Majesty had in this his book interjected a summary of his own faith, and likewise a short declaration of the criminal proceedings in his kingdom, somewhat beside the main scope of his work; whereunto he had been forced by the impertinency of his slanderers, who, leaving the subject in hand, had taxed his person of heresy, and his government of persecution, moving him to clear himself of these defamations, which yet he had done with all moderation, and without any intent of leading other princes farther than the mere point of civil and absolute jurisdiction in their own estates.
And upon this I insisted much, assuring the Prince that his Majesty had given me especial commandment to protest herein the truth of his intention, though (as I said) to them it was less necessary, who had likewise themselves in the time of their own variance, had experience of the malice both of black and cremisin Jesuits, in charging them with heretical opinions; when neither the cause then on foot nor their intent, nor their defenders went farther than the point of temporal authority.
This was the substance, and (as near as I can remember) the whole sense and order of what I then said, in conformity with his Majesty’s letter and the occasion. The letter was publicly read by one of the secretaries; and the Prince having kissed both that and the book with a very cheerful and ingenuous countenance, answered to this effect: That his Majesty (to whom this State was already so much obliged) did not need to heap upon them any more tokens of his love.
That yet whatsoever came from him was dear unto them, especially so precious a work as that must be to which un Re tanto dotto et tanto illuminato had set his own pen, and the dearer for that he perceived both by me, and by his royal and loving letters (which had been read before him) that his Majesty did merely respect the common right of princes senza alcun altro fine quà dentro. That it should in Senate be consulted in what form they might best thank him for such an extraordinary favour; and in the meantime he besought me to represent unto his Majesty how kindly they had received it.
I replied that I would do it willingly, and would inform his Majesty (whereof I knew he would be glad) that he was here rightly understood. These were the passages of that morning.
Your Lordship’s most bound to honour and serve you,
Henry Wotton

letters.incipit: It may please his Majesty to be informed that,
letters.abstract: In this letter, Henry Wotton informs the Earl of Salisbury about the prohibition of King James I’s book, Apologia pro iureamento fidelitatis, in Venice. He attributes the censorship to the Papal Nuncio, who allegedly took advantage of the Doge’s illness to secure the Venetian College’s approval for the ban. Wotton expresses both skepticism and frustration, noting that while the prohibition was issued, it did not explicitly name James I as the author, nor did it impose penalties on booksellers. He employs an informant, Francesco Biondi, to investigate, revealing that copies are expected from Basel, and that a prominent bookseller, Giambattista Ciotti, remains willing to supply them. Wotton characterizes Ciotti as “Jesuitical,” reinforcing his anti-Jesuit conspiratorial lens. He resolves to publicly protest the prohibition and promises a detailed report to James I in his next letter. The letter blends genuine diplomatic concerns with Wotton’s conspiratorial interpretation of Catholic influence in Venice.
letters.transcription:
Letter 167: To the Earl of Salisbury
Source: S. P. Ven., holograph
Subject: The circulation of the King’s book prohibited in Venice
Date: From Venice, 28 August 1609
Style of the place.
Transcription:
Right Honourable and my very good Lord,
It may please his Majesty to be informed that, since the acceptance of his book here in that kind manner (which I have formerly advertised), there hath order been given to all the booksellers of this town, out of the office of the Inquisition, to consign immediately to the General Inquisitor all the copies that have or shall come to their hands of a book intituled Apologia pro iureamento fidelitatis.
This was the precise form of the mandate which, when I first heard, I must confess unto your Lordship that I was much distracted between the just reason which I had to resent it, and as just not to believe it; but having researched the matter to the bottom, I find (by secret intelligence) that the Nuncio here, under the opportunity of the Prince his absence (whose sickness continueth to our inestimable grief), had in College (which is at the present the most superstitious member of the State) procured a consent to the foresaid prohibition, by urging those points of faith comprehended in the Pope’s censure, which I sent his Majesty in my last.
Yet there was observed therein either such cunning or such respect (for I am in doubt how to call it) as not to nominate his Majesty for the author, nor to impose on the booksellers any penalty usual in other like cases. And myself the day after, for trial how far they meant to obey this commandment, employing Francesco Biondi underhand as out of his own curiosity, to deal with one of them for a copy and told him they had been newly in a sort forbidden; ‘but notwithstanding’ (said he) ‘if you return within a few days I hope to furnish you, for we expect some from Basil, where we hear it hath been reprinted.’
This was Giambattista Ciotti, the Sanese, of all our stationers the most Jesuitical. Now, albeit it may appear unto his Majesty by these circumstances that this prohibition will do nothing in this place, but increase the desire and price of the thing prohibited (to which end I have known the like, since my being here, procured by the booksellers themselves), yet on the other side, many and weighty and most infallible considerations do move me to intercede publicly against it; for which purpose I have demanded audience tomorrow.
And by the next post I will render a very particular accompt unto his Majesty both of the motives and of the event. Till when I very humbly leave your Lordship in God’s protection, resting,
Your Lordship’s always most bound to honour and serve you,
HENRY WOTTON.

letters.incipit: Not long since a gentleman
letters.abstract: Henry Wotton reports to the Earl of Salisbury about a dubious French informant, Claudio de’ Giuberti, who claims to have uncovered a plot against King James I in Rome. The informant, allegedly trained at the Papal Court, describes an Englishman seeking revenge for religious persecution, supposedly carrying a stiletto as proof of his intent. Wotton, skeptical of the informant’s credibility, confirms with the French ambassador that he was a known opportunist seeking financial reward. Additionally, Wotton discusses the trial and execution of Fra Fulgenzio Manfredi in Rome, noting that false accusations were made against him regarding correspondence with King James and the English ambassador. Wotton publicly refutes these charges, leading to a strong reaction in the Venetian Senate, reinforcing his role in defending England’s interests.
letters.transcription:
Letter 189 Analysis
Transcription
(Preserving original formatting as closely as possible)
189. TO THE EARL OF SALISBURY.
S. P. Ven., holograph, extract. A Frenchman attempts to get money from the ambassador by a report of a project to kill James I; the trial of Fra Fulgenzio Manfredi.
Venetia, 29th of October, 1610.
… Not long since a gentleman of some forty years (accompanied with another, that seemed rather his friend than servant, though he acted at this time the part of attendance) demanded of my men below some opportunity to speak with me, in such a fashion as they told me it was some point of importance; whereupon leading of him into a chamber (his friend remaining as he would have it without) he began with me after a little pause, very gravely and gnomicallly in this manner: ‘Signore’ (said he) ‘Li Ministri di Principi non debbono disprezzare alcun minimo aviso che appartenga alla salute di lor Padroni.’ To which myself answering, ‘V. Signoria dice pur benissimo,’ he followed, that if himself and his brother had been believed, the French King should be now alive, and withal told me he was by nation French, though bred a long time in the Roman Court.
There his brother was secretary, as I remember, to some cardinal; there himself also had managed great business. That was the school, that was the centre of practice and curiosity, and from thence he was come purposely to tell me a matter touching the safety of the King my master, which was this in substance: that in the church of the Jesuits at Rome, he spied a while since a young gentleman of a desperate countenance; with whom insinuating himself, he found him to be of our nation, and full of open complaint that all his friends had been persecuted for the Catholic faith, and himself thereby impoverished, which had drawn him to the Pope’s feet for relief; and some small matter he had gotten, with which he would return home again.
‘And’ (said he) ‘I have that here in my pocket which, within six months, shall purchase me ten thousand crowns’: wherewithal he showed him a stiletto.
This was the matter that he was come postingly and purposely from Rome to tell me, leaving the farther inferences and deductions to mine own conceit.
Whereupon first I asked him the name of that fellow whereof he had spoken, which he told me he knew not. Then I prayed him to favour me with his own, which after entreaty that I would say nothing of him to the French ambassador, he told me was Claudio de’ Giuberti, or, in his own vulgar, Claude de Jubert.
I was so unmannerly as to ask him why he was so loath to be mentioned to the foresaid ambassador, whereunto his answer was very prompt, lest he might take some shadow at his dealings with me, as there is always (said he) jealousy enough between public instruments.
And so he brake away, methought as not willing to abide more questions, yet with an intention to return within a day or two, and in the meantime he besought me to consider of this service.
The next day, though I perceived sufficiently by what trade he lived, yet being desirous, as was my duty, to have some better accompt of the man, because upon the credit of his condition would depend the credit of his speech, I communicated the matter (notwithstanding his former request) to the French ambassador, who told me who he was, before I had finished to describe him; adding that himself likewise had sundry times been molested with some of his frivolous speculations.
To conclude the whole, he came afterwards unto me, in plain language, for a reward, and went away without it.
For I told him I had considered the value of his tale, and of that idle nameless person, and I wished him to busy himself about better grounded fears; for though there was a late heavy example of the Divine permission, yet it was not so easy an occupation to kill kings as he might peradventure think it.
In these terms we parted.
And although the whole hath not merited the trouble of your Lordship in reading it, yet I hope to be excused with the tender sense of my duty, being fitter for me in all such cases as these to exercise my zeal than my judgement.
There remaineth yet another matter to be represented unto his Majesty, unto which I was drawn with just indignation.
In the process of Fra Fulgenzio the Franciscan, lately executed at Rome, was openly read in the church of St. Peter’s, for one of the mainest articles, that he had held correspondence and practice with his Majesty, through the English ambassador at Venice, about conveying of him thence to London.
This having been related unto me, first by letter, but more authentically by one that was present at the publication of the process, I repeated it here of late at one of my audiences in College: telling them that, though I could not restore that poor soul his life, yet I was bound in honour and conscience, and in the feeling of humanity, to discharge him of all that which had pompously been inserted into his process touching his Majesty and me, the unworthiest of his servants, which I affirmed upon my salvation to be as feigned and as false as I believed all the rest to be of the Roman Court.
Which asseveration, when it was afterwards related verbatim in Senate, your Lordship cannot imagine what a general assent there was of those that cried, ‘Per Dio, l’è vero.’
And so having troubled your good Lordship with discharge of these duties I humbly rest,
Your Lordship’s always bound to honour and serve you,
HENRY WOTTON.

letters.incipit: Questa è la seconda che scrivo
letters.abstract: This letter, written on March 29, 1611, from Venice to De l’Isle Groslot, discusses the political instability in France, the influence of the Jesuits, and the international power dynamics involving Spain, Geneva, and the Duke of Savoy. The author expresses concern over France’s vulnerability to civil war due to Jesuit intrigues and criticizes the perceived passivity in addressing their influence. The letter also references Spain’s decree against Cesare Baronio’s Annales Ecclesiastici, the Duke of Savoy’s erratic political maneuvers, and the broader consequences of Jesuit involvement in German affairs. Additionally, the letter touches upon a controversy in France regarding the Jesuits, the Sorbonne’s decrees, and an apologetic work by Pierre Coton’s associate, Claude de Richeome. The mention of the young King Louis XIII’s limited public presence hints at concerns about governance.
letters.transcription:
CLXXII. — Al signor De l’Isle Groslot.1
Questa è la seconda che scrivo a V.S. per via di Torino: per l’altra le diedi conto della ricevuta di tutte le sue; l’ultima delle quali fu delli 15 febbraio. Al presente accuso la ricevuta di quella del primo stante, per la quale veggo la necessità che ha la Francia di fare qualche buona provvisione contra i Gesuiti; e senza dubbio, sono incompatibili gli interessi dell’una con quelli degli altri. Io credo bene che i Riformati vi penseranno, e che di là nascerà qualche rimedio: altrimente veggo eccitata guerra civile.
Avrà V.S. ricevuto, insieme con la precedente mia, 
[p. 198 modifica]
il decreto di Spagna contro il tomo undecimo di Baronio; il quale, se bene proibisce solo la parte che tocca la monarchia di Sicilia, nondimeno mi pare che sii una macchia a tutta l’opera, e all’autore medesimo ancora, al quale vengono dati epiteti che toccano la coscienza e la realtà dello scrittore.
L’ufficio che V.S. ricorda verso il signor Casaubono, sarà fruttuoso, e procurerò che sia fatto efficace da Wotton, che fu ambasciatore qui. Credo che le gran preparazioni che si fanno per la difesa di Ginevra faranno sfumar tutti i disegni, se pur ve n’erano; perchè quanto a me, credo, che più tosto fossero rivolti a Berna.2 V.S. tenga per certo, che il duca di Savoia è inquieto, e farà qualche gran male a Francia, ovvero a Spagna, ovvero a Italia, ovvero a sè stesso. Non fu buon consiglio che diede Bouillon di mandar il figlio in Spagna, e dubito che la Francia farà sempre di questi errori.3
In Italia non abbiamo alcuna cosa di nuovo, se non che di Spagna hanno levato 13 mila ducati d’entrata al Contestabile, che egli aveva in regno di Napoli; ed è fama che si pensi di levargli anco il contestabilato, che importa d’entrata 11 mila: 
[p. 199 modifica]
cosa che dà da pensare assai, essendo costume di Spagnuoli più tosto di esser prodighi nel donare, che inclinati al contrario. Però queste cose dànno poco da pensare, essendo certo che quel re vuole onninamente la pace in Italia.
Gli occhi di tutti sono rivolti alle cose di Germania, le quali sono di tanto momento e così gran conseguenza, che maggior non si potrebbe pensare. Sopra tutto, io resto pieno d’ammirazione, come, essendo noto a ciascuno che i Gesuiti sono stati autori e istigatori di tutto il male occorso, siano nondimeno esenti dal partecipare ai pericoli ai quali è esposta l’altra parte, e restino sicuri di continuare a far ardere il fuoco maggiormente. Piace così a Dio di acciecar il mondo, che non vegga nella luce del sole.
L’apologia di Richéome è libro troppo grosso da venir col corriere. Non vorrei, che V.S. prendesse questo incomodo, perchè vedrò di farlo capitare a Francoforte, di dove mi verrà con gli altri libri della fiera.
Ho veduto l’apologia che fa per i Gesuiti l’arcidiacono di Rouen: cosa molta artificiosa, però che porge materia di dire assai cose. Se la Sorbona dasse fuori quel decreto che fecero il primo di febbraio, io avrei per singolar favore di riceverne una copia; ma se non lo dànno fuori, non è cosa da curar molto.
Una cosa mi si rende dubbia, della quale desidero esplicazione da V.S. con suo comodo. Il re di Francia è di anni dieci, quando a me pare che l’uomo abbia intelligenza assai, e possi dire — voglio; — e pur non lo sento nominare, come se fosse in fasce. Desidererei che a V.S. fosse dato carico d’andare alla Congregazione generale, e spererei qualche buon frutto: come prego Dio, che si effettui. Il quale 
[p. 200 modifica]
ancora prego che doni a V.S. ogni vero bene; alla quale bacio la mano, insieme col signor Molino e P. Fulgenzio.
Di Venezia, li 29 marzo 1611.

THE ENGLISH TRANSLATION
CLXXII. — To Signor De l’Isle Groslot.
This is the second [letter] I am writing to Your Lordship by way of Turin; in the other, I acknowledged receipt of all your letters, the last of which was from February 15. Presently, I acknowledge receipt of the one from the first of this month, from which I perceive the necessity France has of making some good provision against the Jesuits; undoubtedly, the interests of one are incompatible with those of the other. I do believe the Reformed will give thought to this, and that from there some remedy will emerge; otherwise, I foresee civil war ignited.
Your Lordship will have received, together with my previous [letter],
[p. 198 modifica]
the Spanish decree against Baronius’s eleventh volume, which, although it forbids only the part concerning the monarchy of Sicily, nonetheless seems to me a stain upon the entire work, and also upon the author himself, who is given epithets that impugn both the conscience and honesty of the writer.
The task Your Lordship mentions regarding Signor Casaubon will bear fruit, and I shall ensure it will be effectively done by Wotton, who was ambassador here. I believe that the great preparations being made for the defense of Geneva will dissolve all designs, if indeed there were any; as for myself, I think they were rather directed toward Bern. Your Lordship can be assured that the Duke of Savoy is restless, and he will inflict some great harm either upon France, or upon Spain, or upon Italy, or upon himself. It was not good advice that Bouillon gave in sending his son to Spain, and I fear France will continue to make errors like this.
In Italy, we have nothing new, except that Spain has revoked 13,000 ducats of income from the Constable, which he held in the Kingdom of Naples; and it is rumored they plan to take from him also the constableship itself, which amounts to an income of 11,000 [ducats].
[p. 199 modifica]
This gives much food for thought, as the Spanish are customarily prodigal in giving rather than inclined toward the contrary. However, these things do not cause great worry, as it is certain that this king absolutely desires peace in Italy.
Everyone’s eyes are turned toward the affairs of Germany, which are of such significance and consequence that one could hardly imagine greater. Above all, I remain amazed that, while it is well known that the Jesuits were authors and instigators of all the evil that has occurred, they nonetheless remain exempt from the dangers to which the other side is exposed, and are secure to continue further fueling the fire. It pleases God thus to blind the world, so that it does not see clearly in the sunlight.
The Apology of Richéome is a book too large to send by courier. I would not want Your Lordship to be troubled by this, as I will arrange for it to reach Frankfurt, from where it will arrive to me along with other books from the fair.
I have seen the Apology made on behalf of the Jesuits by the Archdeacon of Rouen—a very crafty thing, as it provides material for many arguments. If the Sorbonne publishes the decree it made on February 1, I would consider it a singular favor to receive a copy; but if they do not publish it, it is not of great concern.
One thing makes me doubtful, about which I desire explanation from Your Lordship at your convenience. The king of France is ten years old, an age at which, in my view, a person has considerable understanding and can say, “I wish it”; yet I do not hear him mentioned, as if he were still in swaddling clothes. I wish that Your Lordship might be entrusted with attending the General Congregation, and I would hope some good fruit would come of it; for this I pray to God, that it may be fulfilled.
[p. 200 modifica]
I also pray to God that He grant Your Lordship every true blessing; to whom I kiss the hand, along with Signor Molino and Father Fulgenzio.
From Venice, March 29, 1611.

 "text_source": "CLXXII. — Al signor De l'Isle Groslot.1\nQuesta è la seconda che scrivo a V.S. per via di Torino: per l'altra le diedi conto della ricevuta di tutte le sue; l'ultima delle quali fu delli 15 febbraio. Al presente accuso la ricevuta di quella del primo stante, per la quale veggo la necessità che ha la Francia di fare qualche buona provvisione contra i Gesuiti; e senza dubbio, sono incompatibili gli interessi dell'una con quelli degli altri. Io credo bene che i Riformati vi penseranno, e che di là nascerà qualche rimedio: altrimente veggo eccitata guerra civile.\nAvrà V.S. ricevuto, insieme con la precedente mia, \n[p. 198 modifica]\nil decreto di Spagna contro il tomo undecimo di Baronio; il quale, se bene proibisce solo la parte che tocca la monarchia di Sicilia, nondimeno mi pare che sii una macchia a tutta l'opera, e all'autore medesimo ancora, al quale vengono dati epiteti che toccano la coscienza e la realtà dello scrittore.\nL'ufficio che V.S. ricorda verso il signor Casaubono, sarà fruttuoso, e procurerò che sia fatto efficace da Wotton, che fu ambasciatore qui. Credo che le gran preparazioni che si fanno per la difesa di Ginevra faranno sfumar tutti i disegni, se pur ve n'erano; perchè quanto a me, credo, che più tosto fossero rivolti a Berna.2 V.S. tenga per certo, che il duca di Savoia è inquieto, e farà qualche gran male a Francia, ovvero a Spagna, ovvero a Italia, ovvero a sè stesso. Non fu buon consiglio che diede Bouillon di mandar il figlio in Spagna, e dubito che la Francia farà sempre di questi errori.3\nIn Italia non abbiamo alcuna cosa di nuovo, se non che di Spagna hanno levato 13 mila ducati d'entrata al Contestabile, che egli aveva in regno di Napoli; ed è fama che si pensi di levargli anco il contestabilato, che importa d'entrata 11 mila: \n[p. 199 modifica]\ncosa che dà da pensare assai, essendo costume di Spagnuoli più tosto di esser prodighi nel donare, che inclinati al contrario. Però queste cose dànno poco da pensare, essendo certo che quel re vuole onninamente la pace in Italia.\nGli occhi di tutti sono rivolti alle cose di Germania, le quali sono di tanto momento e così gran conseguenza, che maggior non si potrebbe pensare. Sopra tutto, io resto pieno d'ammirazione, come, essendo noto a ciascuno che i Gesuiti sono stati autori e istigatori di tutto il male occorso, siano nondimeno esenti dal partecipare ai pericoli ai quali è esposta l'altra parte, e restino sicuri di continuare a far ardere il fuoco maggiormente. Piace così a Dio di acciecar il mondo, che non vegga nella luce del sole.\nL'apologia di Richéome è libro troppo grosso da venir col corriere. Non vorrei, che V.S. prendesse questo incomodo, perchè vedrò di farlo capitare a Francoforte, di dove mi verrà con gli altri libri della fiera.\nHo veduto l'apologia che fa per i Gesuiti l'arcidiacono di Rouen: cosa molta artificiosa, però che porge materia di dire assai cose. Se la Sorbona dasse fuori quel decreto che fecero il primo di febbraio, io avrei per singolar favore di riceverne una copia; ma se non lo dànno fuori, non è cosa da curar molto.\nUna cosa mi si rende dubbia, della quale desidero esplicazione da V.S. con suo comodo. Il re di Francia è di anni dieci, quando a me pare che l'uomo abbia intelligenza assai, e possi dire — voglio; — e pur non lo sento nominare, come se fosse in fasce. Desidererei che a V.S. fosse dato carico d'andare alla Congregazione generale, e spererei qualche buon frutto: come prego Dio, che si effettui. Il quale \n[p. 200 modifica]\nancora prego che doni a V.S. ogni vero bene; alla quale bacio la mano, insieme col signor Molino e P. Fulgenzio.\nDi Venezia, li 29 marzo 1611.",
