letters.incipit: I present herein unto your Majesty
letters.abstract: This letter, written by Sir Henry Wotton to King James I on January 21, 1610, describes how Henry IV of France attempted to undermine Protestant activities in Venice by using an intercepted letter to expose covert Protestant networks. Giovanni Diodati, an Italian Protestant theologian from Geneva, had written to a French official about Protestant affairs in Venice. Somehow, the letter fell into the hands of the Jesuit Father Pierre Cotton, Henry IV’s confessor, who then showed it to the French king. Henry IV forwarded copies to the Pope and the French ambassador in Venice, who delayed its presentation for strategic reasons, possibly waiting for Papalist factions in the Venetian Senate to prepare the ground. Wotton interprets these actions as part of a broader French effort to curry favor with Rome, possibly as preparation for a future alliance or to facilitate the return of the Jesuits to Venice. Wotton also notes a subtle but significant pressure campaign directed at Paolo Sarpi, urging him to seek papal absolution. The letter reflects England’s diplomatic interest in countering Catholic influence in Venice and maintaining its Protestant allies.

letters.incipit: From this place, I determined to make my first Dispatche
If youre Maiestie since my last accompt from Augusta
I will discharge those privat duties
letters.abstract: In this letter dated 4 May 1618 from Venice, Henry Wotton addresses two primary subjects: Doctor Marta and his Lord Rosse. He first discusses complaints and secret business relating to a particular “use” that pertains to his role in state affairs—a matter he hopes to have mediated by the recipient’s honorable influence. Wotton then turns to issues regarding Lord Rosse’s conduct abroad. He reports intelligence that Rosse, accompanied by Diego, voluntarily submitted himself to the Court of Inquisition—an act interpreted by English Jesuits as suspect. The letter further details how Rosse’s behavior appears designed to facilitate the conversion and subsequent liberation of a certain Mr Mole, whose change of faith is linked to Rosse’s example. Wotton also mentions the bearer, Captain Henry Bell, commending his military skill despite his modest fortunes. Overall, the letter interweaves personal complaints, confidential state business, and observations on the shifting religious allegiances among English exiles, reflecting the turbulent political and religious climate of early seventeenth‑century Europe.
letters.transcription:
Right Honorable
I will in this only present through your favourable handes two last particular notes about Doctor Marta and my Lord Rosse.
Page 14
from mine owne aduise but he should rather direct his writings immediatly to his Maiestie or to your handes ; imagining he would be more substantiall when he should send to the Fountayne : for his papers to me were very empty save of complement or importunitie for monies. Now, to speake somewhat farther of him without passion or wrong :
His Ma^ in his verbal instructions at my departure after some precaution about the keeping of him still in appetite referred me in the rest to my Predecessour : from whom I tooke a very right Character of the man : that there was good to be made of him but I should find him full of Neapolitanarie which well translated are shiftes. I came therefore prepared with this information not so much to consider his nature as his Vse. And accordingly when I some tyme after my arrival receaued from him certayne wilde proiects (which I represented to S^ Raph Winwood to his Ma^) I aduised him to beginne some solid worcke touching the Roman Churche : being a practised man in that Court and besides well versed in the Canon lawes — which is the forge of all their abuses : Vppon this perswasion he composed the Booke I sent by one an English Marchant who deliuered the same to S^ Raph Winwood though I never heard more of it. In that Booke was a last Chapter how the Pope doeth gouerne the Princes of his flock : whereof he only sent the Tytle reseruing the treatice craftily enough because he knewe how much I desired it. Hinc illae lachrymae. For from this hath risen all expostulation betweene him and me (as I had aduisement) about his payments (saue onely so much as appeareth in the Bill of extraordinaries) and him still crying to perfect that Chapter as the most meritorious part ; wherein he should well deserue of his Maiestie and of the Christian World by laying open the Roman trickes. I therefore wishe that his Ma^ would be pleased by your letter to take notice in a word or two vnto him of those Chapters that the King hath already receaued (for so I suppose) and expresse his long expectation of the last Chapter and laye the fault vppon me that his petition hath not been payed
Page 15
because I still kept the King in hope of the last and cheefest part. Vppon the receyte whereof his Ma^ meaning was to send him the whole together. Something dressed in this fashion will serue two turnes : bothe to content him and excite him. I haue in the meane tyme intertayned an excuse : first grownded vppon the Kings absence in Scotland then the death of S^ Raph Winwood who was best acquainted with his propositions, and lastly, for want of a particular Patent by vertue whereof such monies as shall be payed him here may be redemaunded at home of my Lord Threasurer. One thing I had almost forgotten which he tooke somewhat vnkindly and vniustly.
I pressed him to finishe the foresayed worcke when he told me he had an other thing in hande de prohibitione librorum whereof the scope was to perswade the Italians to a reading for information of their consciences : wherein I gaue him all possible incouragement as well as in the other : but when he would haue dedicated it to me I refused that curtesie because my name would haue giuen some scandal vnto it before the reading, and so haue frustrated the fruict besides such prayers wherewith he had laden me in the Epistle as would haue taken away all credit from the rest. Howsoeuer, now I see because I was vncapable of his commendations he hath made me the subiect of his complaints : though both vndeseruedly.
I conclude about him let me say no more. He bewrayeth a desire of quitting his profession and retiring vnder your view : If the King shall conceiue more vse of him there then here I will attend his Ma^ good pleasure.
Now, concerning the points required about my L Rosse, I meane how by my intelligence he proceeded at Rome and may be made good vppon his owne promises of returne : honesting his absence (as it seemeth) by some privat end that he aymes at abroade.
Surely to this proceeding he yet is been vnsutable. For at his first arrival in that rotten place even before he had visited his owne Cuntrimen he went with Diego and submitted himself to the Court of Inquisition (thinking as the English Jesuites doe there interpret it who were somewhat distasted that a man of such qualitie did not passe thorough their handes) that such a voluntarie offer would haue been taken without any farther probation, but therein (if that were his drift) he was deceaued. For the Inquisitours did tender him either an oathe or a forme of confession (for in this poynt my intelligence is not cleere) but whatsoeuer it was he swallowed it : which done and voiced among our Cuntrimen they beganne to worcke vppon M^ Mole by his example telling him that my Lord Rosse was become a sound Roman Catholique : when that is so (replies the poore gentleman) I will be so my self. Vppon which words (though spoken a la volee) a gentleman was imployed (see how nimble they are) to wish my Lord Rosse to open his conscience also to M^ Mole whose conuersion did depend vppon his. This brought them together though (for aught I heare yet) to small purpose.
Page 16
Of other particular circumstances of his behaviour there I haue formerly written. What iudgment may be made vppon the whole I leaue to his Ma^ wisedome. For my part, I can conceiue no imaginable pretext of any privat scope that he can haue vnlesse it be to procure M^ Moles libertie by way or couler of conuersion, which I thinke he would hardly alleadge for any excuse of his owne travayles. And thus much in answer of the two poynts required by you. When I shall vnderstande more I will discharge my dutie.
This bearer Captayn Henry Bell was recommended to the State by his Ma^ letters and to me by yours. He hath here increased rather his observation then his fortune. I leaue the report of my endeuours for him to himself. Surely he is a man of great skill and experience in the militarie way, and of a right honest composition in the Civill : but such is the iniquitie of fortune that such a State as this will make a Wassenhouen a Colonel (who was before but a tuner of Virginals) and refuse the offers of an able man. I haue here made with him domestical acquaintance, and found his temper so fayre and discreete that I am bounde (Sir) to reuert those commendations that you sent by him hether vnto your selfe whose loue may more avayle him.
He bringeth a letter from me to the King : wherein I shall then handle the businesse his Ma^ to graunt me leaue to returne towards this next Winter ; by which time I hope this Cuntrie will be at ease ; and I haue been nine yeares his Ma^ servant in this place if I reckon from my beginning and steere if I reckon from my last Commission. So in respect of the tyme it is no irregular request. I humbly beseeche you (Sir) that y^ favourable mediation may make it every way more easy. I confesse this last tyme I haue liued like a decumbent yet seldome in cheerefull health by reason of those distillations from my head into my brest which I found it now in this vaporous ayre : And perhaps I haue lesser vigour to resist it. Besides, though my fortune compasse me not with many occasions : yet of those who wishe me home I may chance a Widoe that will devoure me. In truth I am much bound to y^ Honour for your good offices with the King in my behalf.
And so I rest
Venice this 4^ of May, 1618.
With most desire
to serue you
Henry Wotton.
Page 17
Right Honorable
I will now onely present through your favourable handes two last notes about Doctor Marta and my Lord Rosse.

letters.incipit: I will deal plainly with you
letters.abstract: Writing from Venice on the fourth and fifth of July 1618, Henry Wotton addresses a spectrum of issues: the military and political climate, referencing Don Pedro’s levies and potential threats to Venice or the Emperor amid unrest in Bohemia and Friuli; a diplomatic incident in which a Venetian rower unlawfully detained one of Wotton’s servants, prompting public punishment and a personal apology; English affairs in Venice, including the Archdukes’ court and the delicate balance between neutrality and suspicions of conspiracy; Sir Henry Peyton’s proposals, which lack contractual solidity and require either clear English backing or renegotiation with the Venetian Senate; the possibility of intercepting Jesuit correspondence via an acquaintance in “Augusta,” underscoring intelligence opportunities alongside diplomatic hurdles; and, finally, Wotton’s personal request to return home, seeking letters of revocation and referencing the King’s prospective directives for church matters in overseas plantations.

letters.incipit: I haue beene by letters from the Count Palatine
The cause of this dispatche appeareth in my letter to his Maiestie
I write with all secrecy to let you know
letters.abstract: Cavaliere Pagliarini writes in secrecy to inform Sir Thomas Sherley of escalating tensions between the Pope and the Venetian Republic. He reveals that the Pope intends to issue a Bull of Pius V excommunicating those obstructing the Inquisition’s work. The Republic is resisting these efforts, particularly by protecting Fra Paolo Sarpi, an outspoken critic of papal authority, and granting him a stipend. The letter also touches on political and military matters, mentioning the confirmed alliance between the Prince of Florence and the Queen of Spain’s sister, uncertainty over the Grand Duke’s fleet, and skepticism regarding the feasibility of a Cyprus expedition. Additionally, Don Antonio (Sir Anthony Sherley) has arrived in Naples, asserting influence in the Council but remaining elusive about his reception into the Order of Santiago. There are rumors of his possible travel to Ferrara and the Emperor’s court.

letters.incipit: Hujus operis consutor cùm farraginem
Right trusty and well-beloved
In the first beginning of this duty
letters.abstract: Henry Wotton writes to Lord Zouche from Ingolstadt on October 27, 1590, providing an update on his diplomatic observations. He describes his reception upon delivering Lord Zouche’s letters, noting his interactions with Hubert van Giffen, a prominent jurist at Ingolstadt. Wotton then recounts his encounter with a disgraced Englishman—likely Anthony Sherley—who resents Queen Elizabeth I, blaming her for confiscating his family’s estates and spreading anti-Elizabethan rhetoric. Wotton implies that this Englishman has received “dangerous advice” from his father and suggests that his presence abroad is politically motivated rather than merely personal. The letter also contains intelligence about the papal election, reporting the false news that Cardinal di Santa Severina had been elected Pope under the name Julius IV. He notes the Jesuit College’s reaction to the election, implying Jesuit influence in the process. Wotton promises to send more details from Vienna and closes by reaffirming his loyalty to Lord Zouche.
letters.transcription:
7. To LORD ZOUCHE
Reliq., 4th ed., p. 585
Wotton writes to Lord Zouche at Altdorf of his arrival at Ingolstadt, of a disgraced Englishman he found there, and of the reported election of a new Pope.
Engolstade, this 27 of October, 1590
MOST HONOURABLE,
In the first beginning of this duty unto your Honour, I crave pardon to entreat thus much; that whatsoever I shall be bold by the like means at any time to utter unto your Honour, it may please you to accept no otherwise than spoken with unfeigned troth and faith toward you. You have (my Lord), so far above mine own deserts, held me worthy of your Honour’s love, and charged yourself so much with showing it, as wheresoever I am, I must ever live in the dear remembrance of your good favour, and be glad with all service to testify my regard of it.
I have delivered your Honour’s letters, and for their sake have been right friendly entertained. The Doctor to whom they were directed I found in his lodging, placed very fitly and well in my opinion, and the day of my coming was the third of his reading. Mannering returned the evening before to his master. They are both preparing for England. The man sent for them I was acquainted with before at Brownswick, when I came up the country, where he gave himself forth for a merchant, and his trade at Venice. Now he tells me that his farthest journey then was to this town. Oportet mendacem esse memorem.
I assure your Honour, he brought letters of dangerous advice to the son, from the father then; and not much better in the purpose of his coming now; otherwise, the gentleman might be sent for by a less chargeable means, than a man over the country. The students tell me he never spares our Queen in his common table discourse, but rails impatiently upon her, as having detained from his father, without any cause but her own pleasure, the use of his goods and livings; no doubt upon this ground, giving himself forth for a Baron (which I understand here of him); some cause must be alleged why he maintains not the state of it; which objection is very thoroughly answered, that the Queen detains the money that should do it.
He invited me to supper, and as I came at five to his chamber to inquire him out, he sent me down word by the maid that he was not above.
The Cardinal di Santa Severina is Pope, and surnamed Julius the Fourth. The Jesuit College here is advertised the news from Rome, where their Rector is at this present to salute him in the name of the whole society.
Other occurrences worthy your Honour’s hearing we have none. The particulars of the election, if the town afford it, your Honour shall be advertised from Vienna. And thus (my Lord), commending myself with all duty to your honourable good favour and opinion of me, I beseech God to accomplish unto your Honour, in their best time, the noble desires of your own heart, and so in haste most humbly take my leave.
Your Honour’s in all service,
HENRY WOTTON.

letters.incipit: I have this present returned unto your Honour the book of arms and descents.
letters.abstract: In this letter, dated April 21, 1591, from Vienna, Henry Wotton updates Lord Zouche on various matters, including his return of a book of arms and descents and his difficulties obtaining an architectural model. He describes his failed attempt to secure a drawing of a Lusthaus (pleasure house) from a master architect, who had lent the model to an Italian. Wotton suspects that the architect still possesses it but requires a bribe. Additionally, he reports a discovered plot in Graz to massacre Lutherans, possibly orchestrated by Rome, and how it was foiled when a messenger mistakenly delivered incriminating documents to the wrong Chapel Master. He also provides a colorful account of an Englishman in Vienna, Abraham Miller, whose misadventures reflect both personal folly and the broader tensions between the English and the Austrians regarding employment opportunities.
letters.transcription:
Henry Wotton to Lord Zouche
Written the 21st of April, 1591, in Vienna
MY MOST HONOURED LORD,
I have this present returned unto your Honour the book of arms and descents. The picture of the States of the Empire sitting in Parliament, which belongs to an empty page toward the end of the Dutch book, is likewise sent withal. Concerning the Steganography, I can by none of those means that I advertised this last week of, pass further than I have, and I am afraid I have gone too far, because in your last letters I find some displeasure. No man is more sorry of his own faults than myself, and especially then when I think to have done well, which I let rest as one of my follies to his love and judgment that hath pardoned many of them.
The portraiture of the lust-houses I have not gotten, nor by reason of my short abode here cannot. The reason of failing in my promise is truly this: some eight or nine weeks since I determined to take a painter with me upon the next fair day, which I signified by letter. In the meantime (while I waited on the weather), D. Blotius signified unto me that the Master of his Majesty’s Architecture had it in length, breadth, and height, ready modelled and squared out, with all proportions. I found means quickly to have him moved in my behalf, and myself was present. His answer was unto me that he had lent it out to a certain Italian, who was not as then in Vienna, but to return shortly, upon his first coming home he would meincr gavislich ingedanck sein; those were his very words. I renewed the promise afterwards by others’ means. The Italian was not yet come; yesterday I went myself unto his house in the town, and received answer that he was not in the town, but himself and whole family in a house a mile from hence, where he meant to summer. I walked out unto him, and maintained his promise, who gave me answer, that he had dealt with the Italian, but could not recover it again of him, and besides added that it was a matter of some suspicion; by which word I well perceived that he had it, but without some crowns to still the suspicion I could not come to it.
So is the manner. I would willingly (my good Lord) have offered him secretly that which I easily understood to be his desire, but mine own fury hindered me, and I departed from him in such a chafe, as I would not have given a Dutch heller to have saved his life, that had so little regard to save his promise to me, and consequently mine to your Honour; but I excuse him in this point, and desire to have the whole fault laid upon myself, that trusted a fool so far; I use these unreverent words unto your Honour more than beseems me.
In my last I advertised the general state and condition of the brothers of the house of Austria, with the incident circumstances. We have since received intelligence of a dangerous matter discovered at Graz, where a massacre of the Lutherans should have been committed, and the complot written in ten sheets of paper, with a Bandito (as some, and the most say, receiving from Rome; others, feigning and devising himself), sent by his servant to the Chapel Master in the Jesuit College, commanding him to deliver it to his own hands.
The messenger went unright, and took his way directly to the Chapel Master of the Lutheran side, by error of the word, who read the discourse openly in the Council House, caused the gates to be well guarded, expostulated the matter with the Duke, made the Italian to be drawn in, advertised the Emperor of it by post, and sent the copy withal. His Majesty’s mandate is expected, further we hear not yet.
There is a certain English northern man in this town, born at Newcastle, who hath served the King of Denmark, Sweden, and Poland, travelled the Seventeen Provinces, Moscovia, Livonia, and France, been taken prisoner in Spain, cozened by another Englishman in Italy of all his money and apparel, lives now by sweetening of gloves, shall marry with a concubine of the Jesuits, as some say, but as I hear more probably with a common courtesan, upon condition if he can be made burgher of Vienna.
He hath lately given up a supplication to the Archduke to be entertained in service, and received a round answer that touches our whole nation, that the Dutch can get no service in England, and the English are like to find the like here: but if he want money to bring him home, or buy him some honest apparel, for the honour of his Queen he shall have so much given him. This answer was sent him yesterday by one of the Duke’s servants.
His name is Abraham Miller, of a very low stature, a great drunkard, full of words and lies, not able to keep his own dishonesties close, which he tells with a pride, red-faced; if he come unto your Honour, you may know him by this description.
And thus (my most honoured Lord), craving pardon for the faults of my former letters, which either want of leisure or judgment have been cause of, I leave your Honour to the Almighty’s protection, and myself to the continuance of your friendly love, which I humbly desire.
Your Honour’s servant,
HENRY WOTTON

letters.incipit: Since my last, written unto your Honour from Florence
letters.abstract: This letter from Wotton to Lord Zouche reports on Wotton’s personal illness, the visit of Archduke Maximilian to Rome, and the broader political maneuvering surrounding his visit. Wotton describes Maximilian’s humble attire upon his arrival in Rome, emphasizing his religious piety and the clandestine nature of his interactions with Jesuits and Cardinal Madrutz. The Pope, having recently staged an illness due to a prior political incident, was hesitant to meet the Archduke but eventually did so. There is speculation about the purpose of Maximilian’s visit. Some believed it was to prevent the marriage between the King of Poland (Sigismund III) and a daughter of Austria, but others dismissed this theory in favor of the idea that Maximilian sought Papal intervention to pressure the Emperor into abdicating either the Roman or Hungarian crown in his favor. The letter also notes that the Pope presented Maximilian with a religious relic and a gold medaglia, laden with indulgences—a gesture Wotton dismisses with sarcasm. On a personal note, Wotton discusses his continued residence in Florence at the house of Bacchio Boni, his financial concerns, and his likely stay in Italy over the summer. The letter closes with a request to remain informed of any relevant political affairs.
letters.transcription:
Florence, May 29, 1592
Most Honoured Lord,
Since my last, written unto your Honour from Florence, till this present, I have had a very unquiet time; 

I was with my last journey much distempered, which could not cause less than an ague. In sickness we have care of our life and forget our duties: so that I have rested your Honour’s debtor for the peregrination of the Archduke Maximilian to Rome three posts, which I will now pay. 

His Highness arrived in the city on Tuesday in the Settimana Santa, as they term it, accompanied with three others, of which one went for the master of all. The Archduke was attired in slight leather, without any manner of trimming, his hat buttoned up on the one side, his cloak clasped together in the neck, and turned over upon his shoulder, the one side of his face, and a good part of his forehead, handled like a servant newly come from blacking his master’s saddle. The first, second, and better part of the third day, he spent in religious services, as beholding the relics, visitation of the seven churches, etc.
On Thursday toward evening, he discovered himself to two Jesuits, that were lately come from Vienna, meaning to be brought by them unto the Cardinal Madrutz. 
The Cardinal used practick to bring him to the Pope, which then was not easy, for an accident had fallen out in Rome, that occasioned the Pope to feign himself sick from Thursday before Easter to the Saturday after Easter, as I signified unto your Honour. 
Notwithstanding, Madrutz dealt in it with exceeding diligence, and the Archduke came to conference with the Pope in the Vatican on Friday at night before Easter. 

The cause of his coming was more conjecturable than certain; for though men of great judgment held that it was only to withstand the marriage between the King of Poland and the daughter of Austria, yet wanted not some that said the Archduke had given over those desires. The time was too scant for such an effect, the match crossed not his proceedings; and further, the Pope was not to be dealt with that way, who had delegated some thirty days before the Cardinal Razevil into those parts to no other effect than to consummate the marriage. So that it was rather to be thought he came to have the Emperor solicited by Papal letters to surrender unto him the Roman crown, or that of Hungary: this was the second opinion.
Since his departure (which was presently after the Holy Days), we hear the marriage day (appointed as on the 26th of April past), to have been rejourned till that day three weeks following. Some stirs are expected. The Pope’s present unto him at his leave-taking was a medaglia in gold, of his own person, and a hollow jewel, having in it a piece of the cross on which Christ was crucified (as he made him believe) and annexed unto it an indulgence of 8,000 years (notable religion!).
Touching my private self, I continue in the house of Signor Bacchio Boni, in Via Larga, where I am reasonably well accommodated, but for my ten crowns a month. The times are dear in extremity.
I think to remain in these parts this summer; and, as I imagine, between your Honour’s departure out of Italy and mine, there will be no great difference. If anything occur wherein I may serve your Honour, I beseech it will please you not to let me be ignorant of it. And so (my good Lord), recommending myself unto your most honourable favour and love, I humbly take my leave for this present 29th of May, 1592.
Your Honour’s servant,
Henry Wotton

letters.incipit: I have, for fourteen days,
letters.abstract: Henry Wotton writes to Lord Zouche regarding political and religious intrigue surrounding Lord Darcy in Rome. Darcy, accused of possessing a controversial book by Jesuit Antonio Possevino, faced scrutiny from the Inquisition. The Grand Duke of Tuscany intervened on his behalf, but fears arose that the book’s reprinting would provoke further reprisals. Additionally, Wotton notes accusations of secret correspondences between French exiles and Cardinal Mendoza, potentially leading to severe consequences. Wotton also updates Zouche on his personal situation, including financial concerns, delays in his journey to Venice, and false rumors of his imprisonment by the Inquisition.
letters.transcription:
Henry Wotton to Lord Zouche
Written the 25th of November, 1592, at Sienna
MOST HONOURABLE,
I have, for fourteen days, expected certification from Mr. Hungerford, whether my letters unto him (wherein my last unto your Honour were enclosed) have been delivered; that I might satisfy your Honour’s demands concerning the Frenchman (Lord Darcy) and Monsieur du Plessis (the Lord Treasurer); which I could not conveniently do till my former were received; but being yesterday from my friend advertised that your Honour resided still in Padua, and that my last were recapitated thither, I now proceed to effectuate your will.
That the Frenchman (Lord Darcy) was recommended by Monsieur du Plessis (the Lord Treasurer) to the Master of the Vatican Library (the Grand Duke of Tuscany), I think to be false; neither was there in that packet (of which I wrote your Honour before) any such recommendatory letter; yet he told me that the Master of the Vatican Library (the Grand Duke) had showed him especial favours, which I understand to have been by defending him from the Inquisitor of Rome.
The point stood in these terms. There was a book written against La Noue by Possevinus the Jesuit, comprehending matter of infamous consequence; your Honour knows the imaginations of men; this book, the Frenchman (Lord Darcy), having no other way to resist or retract, bought up all the examples. The matter ascended to about two hundred crowns.
Upon this, the Inquisitor of Rome began to stir against him. The Frenchman (Lord Darcy) solicited the Master of the Vatican Library (the Grand Duke) to back him in it; who authorized the fact, commanding (as far as in him lay) the Inquisitor to silence. The Inquisitor, not daring directly to proceed further, informed the College of it, as the manner is in such cases.
In this deliberation, by the diligence of the Master of the Vatican (the Grand Duke), and gracious speech of Cardinal Mendoza (who greatly favoured the cause of the Frenchman (Lord Darcy), a thing to be noted of some to his great danger), there was no farther dealing against him. But, I hear, one informing him afterwards that the book would be printed again in some other Italian town, and that in the preface there would be some dishonourable mention made of him to his prejudice, he then began to alter his countenance, and very much to repent him that he had ever dealt in it so far.
But howsoever that may prove, sure it is this matter hath mightily kindled the coals against his nation, and greatly enraged the Inquisitor. Especially because he hath been informed that the very same Frenchman (Lord Darcy) hath had his hands in more secret plots, as that he doth exercise a kind of correspondency with a servant of Cardinal Mendoza.
There are likewise others of his nation suspected, so far as perhaps may go near to cost an head or two. As, for better exemplification, I have heard one, with very sound probabilities, accused, during his abode in Rome, at midnight to have entered the house of the forenamed Cardinal, delivering him a packet of letters from his father. I will name the man unto your Honour in my next.
This is all that, by direct or indirect means, is come to my ears.
Concerning mine own estate, I am right sorry that my coming to Venice is rejourned a month or two longer, upon the occasion that I wrote your Honour before, and I do most humbly crave to know (if your good leave afford it me) when your determination is to draw towards England, that I may provide some convenient means to pay your Honour those thirty crowns, to whom I am besides in debt as much as my soul can compass.
Our occurrences, which are many, I will defer till the next ordinary. False news is very current; for I am by Mr. Nevil lately informed that there runs a voice in Venice that I have been in the Inquisition, which, if it be proceeded as far as your Honour, I fear lest it may very much prejudice my credit, that held it from him to whom I am so much bound to reveal all; and therefore do now, to prevent the rumour, affirm it to be false.
Of that other book which I put out in Florence to be copied for your Honour, I have, notwithstanding my writing thither, as yet received no answer; but it shall most certainly be provided for you.
And so recommending myself ever in great particularity to your Honour’s favour and love, and good report of my bad deserts, I leave him for this present in the merciful defence of God.
Your Honour’s servant during his life,
HENRY WOTTON
In Casa d’Alberti, rincontro alla fontana del Casato.
I crave pardon to desire to hear of the receipt of this.
Mr. Hungerford will more diligently convey your letters than Finder.
Being yesterday with Mr. Nevil, he most expressly charged me at my next writing to remember his duty unto your Honour.

  "text_source": "Henry Wotton to Lord Zouche\nWritten the 25th of November, 1592, at Sienna\nMOST HONOURABLE,\nI have, for fourteen days, expected certification from Mr. Hungerford, whether my letters unto him (wherein my last unto your Honour were enclosed) have been delivered; that I might satisfy your Honour’s demands concerning the Frenchman (Lord Darcy) and Monsieur du Plessis (the Lord Treasurer); which I could not conveniently do till my former were received; but being yesterday from my friend advertised that your Honour resided still in Padua, and that my last were recapitated thither, I now proceed to effectuate your will.\nThat the Frenchman (Lord Darcy) was recommended by Monsieur du Plessis (the Lord Treasurer) to the Master of the Vatican Library (the Grand Duke of Tuscany), I think to be false; neither was there in that packet (of which I wrote your Honour before) any such recommendatory letter; yet he told me that the Master of the Vatican Library (the Grand Duke) had showed him especial favours, which I understand to have been by defending him from the Inquisitor of Rome.\nThe point stood in these terms. There was a book written against La Noue by Possevinus the Jesuit, comprehending matter of infamous consequence; your Honour knows the imaginations of men; this book, the Frenchman (Lord Darcy), having no other way to resist or retract, bought up all the examples. The matter ascended to about two hundred crowns.\nUpon this, the Inquisitor of Rome began to stir against him. The Frenchman (Lord Darcy) solicited the Master of the Vatican Library (the Grand Duke) to back him in it; who authorized the fact, commanding (as far as in him lay) the Inquisitor to silence. The Inquisitor, not daring directly to proceed further, informed the College of it, as the manner is in such cases.\nIn this deliberation, by the diligence of the Master of the Vatican (the Grand Duke), and gracious speech of Cardinal Mendoza (who greatly favoured the cause of the Frenchman (Lord Darcy), a thing to be noted of some to his great danger), there was no farther dealing against him. But, I hear, one informing him afterwards that the book would be printed again in some other Italian town, and that in the preface there would be some dishonourable mention made of him to his prejudice, he then began to alter his countenance, and very much to repent him that he had ever dealt in it so far.\nBut howsoever that may prove, sure it is this matter hath mightily kindled the coals against his nation, and greatly enraged the Inquisitor. Especially because he hath been informed that the very same Frenchman (Lord Darcy) hath had his hands in more secret plots, as that he doth exercise a kind of correspondency with a servant of Cardinal Mendoza.\nThere are likewise others of his nation suspected, so far as perhaps may go near to cost an head or two. As, for better exemplification, I have heard one, with very sound probabilities, accused, during his abode in Rome, at midnight to have entered the house of the forenamed Cardinal, delivering him a packet of letters from his father. I will name the man unto your Honour in my next.\nThis is all that, by direct or indirect means, is come to my ears.\nConcerning mine own estate, I am right sorry that my coming to Venice is rejourned a month or two longer, upon the occasion that I wrote your Honour before, and I do most humbly crave to know (if your good leave afford it me) when your determination is to draw towards England, that I may provide some convenient means to pay your Honour those thirty crowns, to whom I am besides in debt as much as my soul can compass.\nOur occurrences, which are many, I will defer till the next ordinary. False news is very current; for I am by Mr. Nevil lately informed that there runs a voice in Venice that I have been in the Inquisition, which, if it be proceeded as far as your Honour, I fear lest it may very much prejudice my credit, that held it from him to whom I am so much bound to reveal all; and therefore do now, to prevent the rumour, affirm it to be false.\nOf that other book which I put out in Florence to be copied for your Honour, I have, notwithstanding my writing thither, as yet received no answer; but it shall most certainly be provided for you.\nAnd so recommending myself ever in great particularity to your Honour’s favour and love, and good report of my bad deserts, I leave him for this present in the merciful defence of God.\nYour Honour’s servant during his life,\nHENRY WOTTON\nIn Casa d’Alberti, rincontro alla fontana del Casato.\nI crave pardon to desire to hear of the receipt of this.\nMr. Hungerford will more diligently convey your letters than Finder.\nBeing yesterday with Mr. Nevil, he most expressly charged me at my next writing to remember his duty unto your Honour.",

letters.incipit: In my last unto your Honour from this town
letters.abstract: Henry Wotton writes from Sienna to Lord Zouche, discussing encrypted correspondence and intercepted letters. He informs Zouche of two books published in Italy against the Lord Treasurer, allegedly connected to a Catholic network involving English contacts. He also describes his recent interactions with Cardinal Robert Bellarmine and his hesitancy about revealing their conversation. Additionally, he comments on European political affairs, including a potential marriage alliance between the Medici and Bavaria, and notes the presence of Jesuits at the courts of Bavarian princes.
letters.transcription:
To Lord Zouche
(Written at Sienna, December 3, 1592)
Most Honourable Lord,
In my last unto your Honour from this town, I made answer to the commandment of your letters received in Florence eight days before my departing thence. The case required close proceeding, which made me use such a manner, as I cannot be understood without receipt of all my former from Sienna. So that upon doubt lest some have miscarried, I have in this included a post-cipher, serving for the letter that I sent by our last ordinary, which was enclosed in one to Mr. Hungerford. I find his means better than that of Pinder.
If your Honour has occasion further to touch any of those points (pleasing him), it shall not be amiss to use the same names. I do in this make haste, being written by the extraordinary; which is here our best course, because otherwise our packets breathe in Florence from Wednesday noon to Sunday morning; so disconvenient is the postage in towns di passaggio, as they term them.
I cannot keep from your Honour that I lately have received information that there are two books written in Italy against my Lord Treasurer, the one in Latin, the other in our vulgar. They were printed in Rome and thought to proceed from one Banes, who is an attendant of our Cardinal, and with whom certain English are run too deep in correspondency. I have about that matter much to deliver in your Honour’s ear I dare not trust; yet this I will venture to signify, that I conjecture there was lately from hence dispatched a man of purpose to obtain an example of those books in Rome, who went upon the Frenchman’s (Lord Darcy’s) charges, of whom I advertised your Honour in my last, and now in the enclosed cipher. This I do hazardously, that your Honour may have it while the action is warm.
Concerning this point, there run certain other suspicions, in part dependent upon it, and partly consequent; which it hath happened unto me to look into with the rest, and hath occasioned me to change my resolution of keeping secret the conference I had with Robert Bellarmine during my abode in Rome, signified your Honour in my first from Florence, and as yet to no other person living.
My reasons are two. First, because it can import me no danger; my second, having proceeded no further with him than to ordinary talk in matter of learning, and besides, as a poor Dutchman. Secondly, I find some (that think their badness secret) so likely to be deceived, as I begin to confess all, fearing lest whatsoever is close has shortly the name of ill; to which estate I see things receive an inclination. In this, your Honour’s advice is humbly desired.
Concerning other points of my estate, I depend upon letters out of England, and am till then nailed in Tuscany. Of my good Lord’s determinations, with his pardon of my boldness, I shall be most glad to hear.
We have for matter of news few effects, but mighty expectations; for it is thought the next promotion at Rome will be very numerous. The two younger princes of Bavaria, Philip, Bishop of Regensburg, and his brother Ferdinando, were seen here this last Friday. They supped with the governor, and dined with the Bailo and departed the next day toward Rome. Their entertainment was gallant here, and the like commanded through all towns of his Highness’s estate, so that we are put into a bisbiglio, and some say, that between the house of Medici and Bavaria there is a match in hand; Maria Medici, the Duke’s niece, doth lose years.
These two princes were accompanied with two Jesuits, who do only sit at their table and suffer ——; a regularity now become the companion of a prince. Out of England, I have very lately received nothing to par—
Your Honour’s servant,
Henry Wotton

letters.incipit: Having in my three last unto your Honour signified by cipher certain dangerous points,
letters.abstract: Wotton reports on political and ecclesiastical matters, particularly the unexpected decision by the Pope not to create new cardinals, despite anticipation. He notes that this primarily affects Cardinal Toledo, who was expected to benefit. He discusses the recent deaths of several cardinals, including Canano and Mondovio, as well as the implications for papal politics. The letter also touches on the travels of two Bavarian princes and their reception at Caprarola, possibly as part of papal maneuvering. There is mention of ongoing shifts within the Grand Duchy of Tuscany, including Don Pietro de’ Medici’s marriage in Spain and Signieur Silvio’s new naval appointment.
letters.transcription:
Reliq., 4th ed., p. 707. Headed ‘Rome (rather Sienna),’ but plainly written from Siena.
Siena. Written this 28th of December, 1592.
Most Honourable,
Having in my three last unto your Honour signified by cipher certain dangerous points, I will in this set down the occurrences in matter of public estate. The great expectation which ran of these last four tempera, concerning the number of cardinals, is fallen out quite contrary; the Pope having on Wednesday morning in the Consistory used to the Illustrissimi these words: “Ora sono Papa, fin ora non son stato Papa, non adJieriro a nessun Principe, non faro de’ Cardinali, Iddio vi benediea”; words directly proceeding against the opinion of all, but crossing none more immediately than the Father Toledo, toward whom the Pope is known to have particular inclination.
Thus much is certain, that Toledo, having given order to one of the Buonacorsi in this town to be ready upon his call, did dispatch a courier for him the Saturday before the four tempora, something seeming to have fallen between the calicem supremaque labra. The College hath lately lost the Cardinals Canano, Mondovio, and Sans. The first died in Modena, to the especial discomfort of the house of Este, as if all stars that gave light that way were under the horizon. By the death of the other two, the Conclave hath received little alteration; though Mondovio were papable, and a great soggetto in the list of the forestieri, and sometime schoolmaster to the King of France.
The two princes of the house of Bavaria (who passed by these parts toward Rome, as it were making haste), were entertained a while at Caprarola upon the Pope’s commandment, that things might be prepared the better in the meantime, as it is interpreted. Of the elder brother’s promotion there is now general silence, men seeing servitors of the Court, and even nephews neglected; which, some say, the Pope hath done to conclude his first year with a point of great moderation.
In the Great Duke’s estate there is little change, or inclination to change, save that Signieur Silvio is made admiral of his galleys; either for his own sufficiency that way, or (as some think) to sweeten the humours of that family, not a little inasperated by the death of Alfonso. Don Pietro di Medici we hear to be married in Spain to the daughter of the Duke of Alba Regale, having obtained of the King the chancellorship of the great Order of St. Jago.
The marriage of the Prince Doria with the daughter of Marcantonio Colonna (sometime Viceroy in Sicily) hath been gallantly celebrated in Genoua. The elder Baron of Harrach is expected daily to pass by these parts, as the Emperor’s lieger in Rome, whom I hear to be a gentleman of very mature judgment.
The death of the Duke of Parma hath put many into disputation about the successor, and some are of opinion that the King will divide the charges, placing in the Low Countries two persons, the one regent for his Majesty, the other Lieutenant-General over the garrisons, artillery, munition, and all points military. The Prince’s death was in the manner of a dropsy, occasioned through drinking of too much water, which was counselled him against his gout. His Requiem they sang in Rome on the seventeenth of the present, the Cardinal Duartes, his son, as then retired out of the city. It is said to have caused some slight mutiny in Antwerp.
The effects that are to follow will, I hope, afford me better matter for my next unto your Honour, of whose estate I most humbly desire to hear. And so in great haste (my good, good Lord) I commend myself unto the continuance of your Honour’s favour and love towards me, wishing him in earnest a blissful end of his designs.
Your Honour’s most faithful servant,
H. Wotton.

Reliq., 4th ed., p. 707. Headed ‘Rome (rather Sienna),’ but plainly written from Siena.
Siena. Written this 28th of December, 1592.
Most Honourable,
Having in my three last unto your Honour signified by cipher certain dangerous points, I will in this set down the occurrences in matter of public estate. The great expectation which ran of these last four tempera, concerning the number of cardinals, is fallen out quite contrary; the Pope having on Wednesday morning in the Consistory used to the Illustrissimi these words: “Ora sono Papa, fin ora non son stato Papa, non adJieriro a nessun Principe, non faro de’ Cardinali, Iddio vi benediea”; words directly proceeding against the opinion of all, but crossing none more immediately than the Father Toledo, toward whom the Pope is known to have particular inclination.
Thus much is certain, that Toledo, having given order to one of the Buonacorsi in this town to be ready upon his call, did dispatch a courier for him the Saturday before the four tempora, something seeming to have fallen between the calicem supremaque labra. The College hath lately lost the Cardinals Canano, Mondovio, and Sans. The first died in Modena, to the especial discomfort of the house of Este, as if all stars that gave light that way were under the horizon. By the death of the other two, the Conclave hath received little alteration; though Mondovio were papable, and a great soggetto in the list of the forestieri, and sometime schoolmaster to the King of France.
The two princes of the house of Bavaria (who passed by these parts toward Rome, as it were making haste), were entertained a while at Caprarola upon the Pope’s commandment, that things might be prepared the better in the meantime, as it is interpreted. Of the elder brother’s promotion there is now general silence, men seeing servitors of the Court, and even nephews neglected; which, some say, the Pope hath done to conclude his first year with a point of great moderation.
In the Great Duke’s estate there is little change, or inclination to change, save that Signieur Silvio is made admiral of his galleys; either for his own sufficiency that way, or (as some think) to sweeten the humours of that family, not a little inasperated by the death of Alfonso. Your Honour’s most faithful servant,
H.
